metadata.title: Classification Algorithm Using Probability Patterns | by Tekin Evrim Ozmermer | Towards Data Science
metadata.description: A classification algorithm modeled by human brain structure is explained in the article.

all_paragraphs: Hello the people who are interested in artificial intelligence and human brain. According to my delusions, I modeled the neurons in human brain. According to the model, I created a classification algorithm. The algorithm works pretty well and, it is unique. I implemented the algorithm in Python, and you can see the test results also given below. I also share the code in GitHub and add the link here.
To understand the all concept, I suggest you to read some subjects before you start. If you already have knowledge on these subjects, then just continue reading.
Image Filtering, Neurons, Matrices(I do not add a link for this one, you can find information about matrices everywhere)
Classification in Machine Learning, Decision Trees, Naive Bayes Classifiers, AdaBoost, Random Forest, Neural Networks

This article focuses on filtering algorithms’ structure used in image processing. The novel algorithm is based on binary matrices of input data to create sub-clusters which are used as filters later in classification. These sub-clusters are called Probability Kernels. The developed algorithm was tested using different data-sets and shows various accuracy rate which depends on diversity of data-set and the matching value which is used for comparison of matrices. Diabetes data-set, Breast Cancer data-set and Ionosphere data-set are used for comparison of performance of the developed algorithm and already known algorithms such as Naïve Bayes, AdaBoost, Random Forest and, Multilayer Perceptron. Test results regarding accuracy rate confirm advantages of proposed algorithm.
If you directly want to jump to algorithm directly, go to section “How does the algorithm work in general?”
The proposed algorithm creates a model (probability kernels) by training data to predict the classes of test data.
The algorithm is created by the sense of how human brain works. The assumption of how human brain works is mentioned below.
The deterministic approach accepts that if the all information in the universe could be known, the future condition could be predicted completely true. The algorithm also employs this approach.

Connections show which attributes are the condition of each concept. Connections are mostly between attributes and concepts. But they also can be between concepts as well. Some concepts can behave as attributes for other concepts. In this condition, concept will be attribute and, the result of the concept will be the value of that attribute.
Each element and attribute in the theory is assumed as a neuron in human brain. Each connection refers to an axon between neurons.

The abolishment of concepts and attributes refers to resetting of used neurons. The abolishment cannot be made by human itself. The process is executed automatically.

When a person learns a concept with an attribute list, the attribute list may be wrong. To remove the wrong attributes, the person needs to repeat the true attributes and the belonged concept several times. By this, wrong attribute that is recorded as the attribute belongs to the concept, will not have any electrical signal passing by. The human brain resets the neurons which do not pass any electrical signal.
This is also related to forgetting concepts and attributes in human brain. If a neuron with an attribute or a concept is not used, the neuron is reset.
1. Algorithm converts the 1-row records to 2-dimensional matrices.
2. Algorithm compares the created 2-dimensional matrices with each other.
2.1. Only the matrices which belong to same class are compared with each other.
3. According to the comparison result, algorithm merges the similar matrices.
3.1. The merged matrices will behave like a filtering kernel in the algorithm. Merged matrices are called as probability kernels in the algorithm.
3.2. After the matrix merging process is done, created probability kernels are used for testing.
4. In testing process, each test record which are also converted to images will be compared with probability kernels which are created by training matrices.
5. At the end of testing process, we get an array of test results. Only the wrong classified records’ test results are stored for training correction.
6. The probability kernels which causes wrong classification are determined from stored test results.
7. After the misleading probability kernels are removed from the probability kernel list, we turn back to process 4.
7.1. This process goes on until we have no more probability kernels.
7.2. Then, the step of this process which gave best accuracy results is recorded.
8. Probability kernels in the step determined above are created again.
9. The best accuracy rate probability kernels that are created above are saved as the prediction model.
The algorithm employs 2-dimensional matrices as input. These 2-dimensional matrices are binary matrices. The conversion process is explained step by step below:
1. Map each value in the record to a range that doesn’t cause a big matrix. For example, maximum value in the records should be 100.
2. Create a zeros matrix with dimensions: Row — Maximum value in the records, Column — Number of columns in a record.
3. Select a record, take the order of first column(C) and the value in that column (V). Put 1 to the matrix in the index: Row — Value we took (V), Column — Order of column we took ©.
4. Go on the process above until you finish mapping all the values in the record.
2. In comparison function, you need to have 2 inputs. The inputs are the matrices which will be compared.
3. In comparison function, take the input matrices and multiply them with each other.
4. In comparison function, sum the new matrix created by multiplication.

5. In comparison function, divide the new matrix created by the summation by the number of ones in the first input matrix. The result will be between 0 and 1. 1 refers to “most similar”, 0 refers to “not similar at all”.
1. Take the similar matrices and, sum them all.
2. Divide the new matrix created by summation of all similar matrices by the maximum value in the same matrix.
By the merging process, we created probability kernels. Now, let’s compare them with the test records. The process is made as given below:
1. Multiply the test matrix with each probability kernel.
2. Sum all the values in the new matrix created by multiplication above. This will be the matching result.
3. Append the matching result and class of probability kernel to a list.
4. Sort the list descending according to the matching results.
5. Take the class of first element in the sorted list (SL) mentioned above.
6. The taken class is the result of classification made by algorithm.
1. Store wrongly classified test results’ matching result and probability kernel order from SL.
1. Determine the index of probability kernels (TPK) which gives true class in the sorted list (SL).
2. Remove all the probability kernels which give higher matching results than TPK in the SL from the probability kernel list.

After the misleading probability kernels are removed from the probability kernel list, we turn back to process 4. Go on the process until you have no more probability kernels. Then, monitor the test results and find the step that gives best accuracy results. That step is the step you need to stop eliminating the probability kernels.
For other algorithms performance, the tool Weka 3.7 is used.
Diabetes Data-set: Training Set 500 records, Testing Set 276 records
Breast Cancer (Original) Data-set: Training Set 465 records, Testing Set 233 records
Ionosphere Data-set: Training Set 234 records, Testing Set 116 records
